newsitem.title: TUNISIA: Libya says Lockerbie trial in neutral country.
newsitem.headline: Libya says Lockerbie trial in neutral country.

text.p: Libya's top decision-making body reiterated on Thursday that the North African country would allow two of its citizens to stand trial in a neutral country for their alleged role in bombing a U.S. airliner over Britian.

The General People's Congress urged world states to ignore U.N. sanctions imposed on Libya for its refusal to hand over the two suspects in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jumbo-jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, in which 270 people were killed.

"Libya does not object to have the two suspects stand for trial before a just and fair court in a neutral country to be agreed on," the congress said in a resolution issued at its annual meeting broadcast live by the state-run Libyan television monitored in Tunis.
It urged other countries not to be bound by "unjust measures imposed on Libya" and said each country's attitude to the sanctions would affect future political and economic ties with Libya.
"The first step would be the exchange of air flights," it said.

The United Nations Security Council slapped sanctions including an air and arms embargo on the oil-producing country in 1992 to back the demand that it hand over the two suspects for trial in the United State or Britain.
Washington and London insist the trial must be in the United States or Britain.
